Definition.Document:
Transformer Health using Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA)

Objective

Knowing when to maintain one of the most critical components within the electrical network, the power transformer, is a unique challenge.  Transitioning from a calendar-based maintenance plan to a condition-based plan requires the synthesis of information from a variety of data sources.  This might include:

  • nameplate characteristics
  • fluid test results
  • diagnostic tests (such as dissolved gas analysis and electrical tests)
  • maintenance and financial history 
  • real-time data (such as cooling performance)

Developing and refining transformer health analytics that take advantage of all of the data is arduous, especially when applied to numerous assets.  This workbook provides an example of one such analytic, Dissolved Gas Analysis, and demonstrates how it can easily integrate with multiple data sources and scale across a fleet of transformers. 

Dissolved Gas Analysis Overview

DGA is the study of dissolved gases in transformer oil.  Transformer oil is used to insulate the transformer's electrical equipment.  When it breaks down, it releases gases within the oil.  The distribution of these gases can be related to the type of electrical fault, and the rate of gas generation can indicate the severity of the fault.  DGA provides an inside view of a transformer.  By analyzing dissolved gases, we can observe the inner condition of any transformer.  Many faults like arcing, overheating, and partial discharge can only be detected by analyzing gases.

Many electrical utilities have a DGA program.  This typically consists of manually sampling the oil and sending the sample to a laboratory for analysis (every 1-4 years).  There are a number of industry-recognized methods used to translate the lab results into fault codes.  A few examples are described below.

Link to Organizer Topic

Assemble Data

Process Data

  • Find Station 191, Transformer 1 - step
  • Load and temperature data is stored in PI - step

Lab Test Data 

  • DGA test results are stored in an SQL database - workstep

Apply analytics

Select from a variety of methods to translate the lab results into fault codes.  Some examples are described below.  Additional options include:

  • Roger's ratio
  • Dornenburg's state estimation
  • Duval's triangle

IEEE C57-104 Total Dissolved Combustible gases (TDCG)

  • Use Formula to add the dissolved gas test results together to find the Total Dissolved Combustible Gases (TDCG) - workstep

($h2+$ch4+$c2h2+$c2h4+$c2h6+$co)
  • Use Value Search and the IEEE Key Gas Analysis Table below to convert the TDCG into operating conditions - workstep (note conditions 3&4 do not appear in our data)

  • Use Treemap to identify transformers operating in perilous conditions across the region - workstep

IEC 60599

  • Use Formula to calculate the IEC Gas Ratios shown in the table below - workstep

 

  • Use Formula and the IEC Analysis Ratio Limits table below to convert the IEC Gas Ratios into fault conditions - workstep

  • Use Treemap to identify transformers operating in perilous conditions throughout the region - workstep

Custom Algorithm

  • If the customer wants to use a custom algorithm instead of an industry standard, they can use Formula to implement in Seeq
  • For example, in our Grid AI Transformer Algorithm signal, we are using the TDCG signal calculated during the IEEE analysis, the acetylene content, the water content, and a real-time signal (KVD877) to calculate a custom health score and generate operating conditions - workstep
  • We can then swap to a sister asset - workstep
  • And compare across a fleet of transformers using Treemap - workstep 

Duval's Triangle on SDL

  • Load all the gas components signal to the Details panel
  • Use the Duval's Triangle Add-on Tool or SDL Project to generate the Transformer's Fault Condition and a Duval Triangle DGA to identify the Fault types. - workstep
  • To detect the Fault condition, one can check for the TDCG Condition 3 using Table 1 and 2. If the total dissolved gas is at Condition 3 AND any of the gas components also meet the condition, the transformer is said to be Faulty.

 

  • Another way to detect the Fault Condition is to check if any gas components are above the L1 Limit and if any gases' generations are above G2 Limit based on Table 3.
  • Once executed, the SDL project will generate the Duval Triangle as per picture below.

  • The Duval Triangle Fault Condition will also be pushed back to this Workbench - workstep
  • The Topic will also be updated with the image of the Duval Triangle.

Duval's Triangle on Workbench

Objective: Build Duval Triangles 

Part A: Create Conditions for Duval Triangle's Regions

  • Load the signal for C2H, C2H4, and CH4 - workstep
  • Use a formula to calculate the component percentages - workstep
  • Build the seven region boundaries using formula - workstep. Reference of the coordinates for the boundaries: https://www.pospeev.com/post/plotting-the-duval-triangle.

  • Combine all conditions using combineWith() and name them using setProperty() - workstep. Then convert the capsule properties to a continuous signal - workstep

Part B: Fault Condition

  • TDCG Limits
    • Load signals - workstep
    • Define TDCG, and use formula to compare each compound with its TDCG limit in Table 1 - workstep
    • Use formula to create condition if TDCG meet and at least one compound meets TDCG limit in Table 1 - workstep
  • L1 Limit
    • Use formula to define L1 limit based on Table 3 - workstep
    • Then compare each component monthly generation rates to G2 Limit in Table 3 - workstep
    • Use formula to create condition when both L1 limit and G2 limit are met - workstep

Combine both TDCG limit and L1 limit using formula - workstep

Part C: Combine Part A (Duval Triangles regions) and Part B (Fault condition) using composite condition - workstep

Part D: Build Asset Tree - Final View

Results

  • Rapid iteration and refinement of analytics to identify assets for targeted, condition-based maintenance
  • Improved reliability, reduced maintenance costs, helps to predict opex, extend the life of the transformer
  • Maintaining transformer vs replacing transformer
  • Reduction in catastrophic asset failures ($10s of millions per transformer)
  • Minimize corporate exposure from preventable failures and outages
  • Connect data, get it all in one place
  • Maintain one version of the truth
  • Easily build your own transformer health algorithms - retain your SME knowledge

Transformer Health using Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA)

Objective

Knowing when to maintain one of the most critical components within the electrical network, the power transformer, is a unique challenge.  Transitioning from a calendar-based maintenance plan to a condition-based plan requires the synthesis of information from a variety of data sources.  This might include:

  • nameplate characteristics
  • fluid test results
  • diagnostic tests (such as dissolved gas analysis and electrical tests)
  • maintenance and financial history 
  • real-time data (such as cooling performance)

Developing and refining transformer health analytics that take advantage of all of the data is arduous, especially when applied to numerous assets.  This workbook provides an example of one such analytic, Dissolved Gas Analysis, and demonstrates how it can easily integrate with multiple data sources and scale across a fleet of transformers. 

Dissolved Gas Analysis Overview

DGA is the study of dissolved gases in transformer oil.  Transformer oil is used to insulate the transformer's electrical equipment.  When it breaks down, it releases gases within the oil.  The distribution of these gases can be related to the type of electrical fault, and the rate of gas generation can indicate the severity of the fault.  DGA provides an inside view of a transformer.  By analyzing dissolved gases, we can observe the inner condition of any transformer.  Many faults like arcing, overheating, and partial discharge can only be detected by analyzing gases.

Many electrical utilities have a DGA program.  This typically consists of manually sampling the oil and sending the sample to a laboratory for analysis (every 1-4 years).  There are a number of industry-recognized methods used to translate the lab results into fault codes.  A few examples are described below.

Assemble Data

Process Data

  • Find Station 191, Transformer 1 - step
  • Load and temperature data is stored in PI - step

Lab Test Data 

  • DGA test results are stored in an SQL database - workstep

Apply analytics

Select from a variety of methods to translate the lab results into fault codes.  Some examples are described below.  Additional options include:

  • Roger's ratio
  • Dornenburg's state estimation
  • Duval's triangle

IEEE C57-104 Total Dissolved Combustible gases (TDCG)

  • Use Formula to add the dissolved gas test results together to find the Total Dissolved Combustible Gases (TDCG) - workstep

($h2+$ch4+$c2h2+$c2h4+$c2h6+$co)
  • Use Value Search and the IEEE Key Gas Analysis Table below to convert the TDCG into operating conditions - workstep (note conditions 3&4 do not appear in our data)

  • Use Treemap to identify transformers operating in perilous conditions across the region - workstep

IEC 60599

  • Use Formula to calculate the IEC Gas Ratios shown in the table below - workstep

 

  • Use Formula and the IEC Analysis Ratio Limits table below to convert the IEC Gas Ratios into fault conditions - workstep

  • Use Treemap to identify transformers operating in perilous conditions throughout the region - workstep

Custom Algorithm

  • If the customer wants to use a custom algorithm instead of an industry standard, they can use Formula to implement in Seeq
  • For example, in our Grid AI Transformer Algorithm signal, we are using the TDCG signal calculated during the IEEE analysis, the acetylene content, the water content, and a real-time signal (KVD877) to calculate a custom health score and generate operating conditions - workstep
  • We can then swap to a sister asset - workstep
  • And compare across a fleet of transformers using Treemap - workstep 

Duval's Triangle on SDL

  • Load all the gas components signal to the Details panel
  • Use the Duval's Triangle Add-on Tool or SDL Project to generate the Transformer's Fault Condition and a Duval Triangle DGA to identify the Fault types. - workstep
  • To detect the Fault condition, one can check for the TDCG Condition 3 using Table 1 and 2. If the total dissolved gas is at Condition 3 AND any of the gas components also meet the condition, the transformer is said to be Faulty.

 

  • Another way to detect the Fault Condition is to check if any gas components are above the L1 Limit and if any gases' generations are above G2 Limit based on Table 3.
  • Once executed, the SDL project will generate the Duval Triangle as per picture below.

  • The Duval Triangle Fault Condition will also be pushed back to this Workbench - workstep

    • Load signals - workstep

    • Then compare each component monthly generation rates to G2 Limit in Table 3 - workstep
    • Use formula to create condition when both L1 limit and G2 limit are met - workstep

Transformer Health using Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA)

Objective

Knowing when to maintain one of the most critical components within the electrical network, the power transformer, is a unique challenge.  Transitioning from a calendar-based maintenance plan to a condition-based plan requires the synthesis of information from a variety of data sources.  This might include:

  • nameplate characteristics
  • fluid test results
  • diagnostic tests (such as dissolved gas analysis and electrical tests)
  • maintenance and financial history 
  • real-time data (such as cooling performance)

Developing and refining transformer health analytics that take advantage of all of the data is arduous, especially when applied to numerous assets.  This workbook provides an example of one such analytic, Dissolved Gas Analysis, and demonstrates how it can easily integrate with multiple data sources and scale across a fleet of transformers. 

Dissolved Gas Analysis Overview

DGA is the study of dissolved gases in transformer oil.  Transformer oil is used to insulate the transformer's electrical equipment.  When it breaks down, it releases gases within the oil.  The distribution of these gases can be related to the type of electrical fault, and the rate of gas generation can indicate the severity of the fault.  DGA provides an inside view of a transformer.  By analyzing dissolved gases, we can observe the inner condition of any transformer.  Many faults like arcing, overheating, and partial discharge can only be detected by analyzing gases.

Many electrical utilities have a DGA program.  This typically consists of manually sampling the oil and sending the sample to a laboratory for analysis (every 1-4 years).  There are a number of industry-recognized methods used to translate the lab results into fault codes.  A few examples are described below.

Select from a variety of methods to translate the lab results into fault codes.  Some examples are described below.  Additional options include:

  • Roger's ratio
  • Dornenburg's state estimation
  • Duval's triangle

  • Use Formula to add the dissolved gas test results together to find the Total Dissolved Combustible Gases (TDCG) - workstep

  • For example, in our Grid AI Transformer Algorithm signal, we are using the TDCG signal calculated during the IEEE analysis, the acetylene content, the water content, and a real-time signal (KVD877) to calculate a custom health score and generate operating conditions - workstep

  • And compare across a fleet of transformers using Treemap - workstep 

Duval's Triangle on SDL

  • Load all the gas components signal to the Details panel
  • Use the Duval's Triangle Add-on Tool or SDL Project to generate the Transformer's Fault Condition and a Duval Triangle DGA to identify the Fault types. - workstep
  • To detect the Fault condition, one can check for the TDCG Condition 3 using Table 1 and 2. If the total dissolved gas is at Condition 3 AND any of the gas components also meet the condition, the transformer is said to be Faulty.

 

  • Another way to detect the Fault Condition is to check if any gas components are above the L1 Limit and if any gases' generations are above G2 Limit based on Table 3.

Part A: Create Conditions for Duval Triangle's Regions

  • Load the signal for C2H, C2H4, and CH4
  • Use a formula to calculate the component percentages
  • Build the seven region boundaries using formula. Get the coordinates to set the boundary by referring to this page: https://www.pospeev.com/post/plotting-the-duval-triangle.
  • Combine all conditions using combineWith() and name them using setProperty(). Then convert the capsule properties to a continuous signal.

Part B: Fault Condition

  • TDCG Limits
    • Define TDCG, and use formula to compare each compound with its TDCG limit in Table 1

    • Use formula to define L1 limit based on Table 3
    • Then compare each component monthly generation rates to G2 Limit in Table 3
    • Use formula to create condition when both L1 limit and G2 limit are met 
  • Combine both TDCG limit and L1 limit using formula
